title: Right Riemann sum - Kathleen skating on a track

content.description:
t (seconds)

0
 3
 5
 8
 12

k(t) (feet per second)

0
 5
 10
 20
 24

Kathleen skates on a straight track. She starts from rest at the starting line at time t = 0. For <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo><</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>12</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3BF7@</annotation> </semantics> </math> seconds, Kathleen’s velocity k, measured in feet per second, is differentiable and increasing. Values of k(t) at various times t are given in the table above.
content.question: Use a right Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>12</mn> </mrow> </msubsup> <mi>k</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4048@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Indicate units of measure. Is this approximation an overestimate or an underestimate for the value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>12</mn> </mrow> </msubsup> <mi>k</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4048@</annotation> </semantics> </math>? Explain your reasoning.

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
